citation.abstract:
To identify the better of the two treatment strategies, single stage versus two stages to create multiple -tracts in mini-percutaneous nephrolithotomy for the treatment of staghorn stone.
Records of patients who underwent MPCNL with multiple -tracts for the treatment of staghorn stones from 2011 to 2013 were retrospectively reviewed. Two-stages (as group 1) and one-stage strategies (as group 2) to establish the multiple -tracts were performed. A total of 145 pairs were matched for the analysis according to age, preoperative hemoglobin, preoperative urine culture, stone surface area, and stone size.
45.5% of success rate of patients in group 2 were achieved after a single procedure with a mean of 2.63±0.62 tracts. The remaining patients required a second procedure, necessitating the placement of multiple tracts or the use of the existing tracts again. The final success rate was similar in both Group 1 and Group 2 (82.1% vs. 84.2% (p=0.638). There was a significantly decrease in the mean number of total access tracts, infection complications, and blood transfusion rate in Group 1 than in Group 2. The infection and bleeding complications were similar for both Groups during the subsequent treatment.
The two-stage MPCNL treatment plan for staghorn stones was more advantageous for two reasons: (1) Almost half of the patients who were treated using a one-stage treatment plan required subsequent procedure to achieve a satisfactory success rate. (2) An initial treatment plan using the two-stage approach resulted in less complication and less tracts established.
citation.title: Comparison of One-Stage versus Two-Stages Multiple –tracts Mini-Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy for the Treatment of Staghorn Stones: A Matched Cohorts Analysis
